title: Vertex K8400 Pince plateau chauffant articulée

description.text:
Après avoir installer un plateau chauffant sur la Vertex K8400,
J'ai cherché une solution qui ressemble au système d'origine que je trouve pratique pour le maintenir en place.
Mais qui ne peut plus être utilisé car l'épaisseur du plateau est bien plus importante. Voila le résultat. Un simple pivotement des 4 pinces qui restent en place sur le châssis en aluminium du plateau, et je sort la plaque en verre.

Printer:

Vertex K8400

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Utilisez de l'ABS pour ces pièces, car j'ai testé avec du PLA et à l'utilisation, la chaleur du plateau ramolli trop le plastique. Du coup les pinces se déforment.
La fixation est assurée à l'aide de la rondelle et de la vis d'origine.

title: Knob With Encased Hex Head Screw

description.text:
This is a knob designed to encase a 1/4" hex head cap screw. Because it can be used with any length cap screw, it's useful in a wide range of applications. The plug covers and secures the screw while making for a nice finished look. Works great as a camera or flash mounting knob.
The plug is designed with a lip to snap into the knob and hold the screw in place while it finishes the look of the knob. You will have to print the plug at a reduced size to make it fit correctly into the knob. Because everyone's printer prints slightly different, I have not tried to size the plug exactly. You will need to run the plug at a few XY scales to make the fit perfect. For me running the plug at 96% works great.
It is designed for a 1/4-20 screw but could also be used with a 6M screw if printed at approximately 95%. I have not tested this but it should work with a range of screw diameters by changing the print scale to match the screw diameter.

• Print the knob part.
  • Print the plug at a reduced size (see notes above).
  • Insert the hex head machine screw. If the screw fits loosely, it can be secured with a few drop of epoxy around the hex head.
  • Snap the plug in place. The larger lip of the plug goes in first. Start the plug at an angle to seat one side and then press the high side in with a vice or pliers. The knob has a recess that matches the plug so it should hold in place without glue and be removable by taping the screw out.

Clip-on side fan mount for the Printrbot Original. Clips on to the X motor mount, and uses two 1" 6-32 screws to attach a 40mm fan to the mount. Clears the print carriage when you home it.  
Blows cool air past the center of the print bed, to keep a cool breeze passing by your print and print head. Helps improve bridging. Not as effective as an on-carriage fan, but it makes it easier to watch your print!  
SketchUp model included for derivatives and adjustments to fit your printer, but it fits parts printed on a Prusa-Mendel and Printrbot Original perfectly!

A small hexacopter (250-ish) that humms like a hummingbird :) The arms fold so it's easier to transport. All arms have a slight angle to counteract negative effects of propwash when descending. Mounting holes are for a KK2.0 board but a remix should be easy for other FC's.

Does not need a whole lot of infill. Best to print the spacers while laying flat.

This is a vape holder for 6-30ml unicorn bottles and two box mods. The two box mods I have this setup for are the Istick 100w and the Snow wolf 200w.  I designed this to fit inside my custom center console in my truck.

After the successful X axis cable chain by brogio99 he published the Z axis chain. I downloaded it, printed it and found out it did not fit. Here is an improved version, based on his VerticalClamp_nema99.stl. My Guide X motor.stl replaces this clamp. The Guide X switch.stl leads the wires from the X switch around the Z axis T8 screw to the top of the guide on the X motor. From there I use brogio99's PD3R...link.stl to the Guide Bottom.stl which is screwed on the Z motor.
On the pics you still see the Fast-and-Rough prints I used for prototyping
I had to open the back of the PD3R links since the plug of the X motor does not fit through so if anybody feels the urge to design better links please feel free to do so, keeping this in mind.

Printer:

Sunhokey Prusa I3 2015

Rafts:

No

Yes

70

Notes: Use a Zip Tie to fasten the X motor guide and existing (or slightly longer) M3 screws for the other two.

I liked the can holder put up by "ilmandorlone", but found it too short for the common12oz cans around here (Maryland). So I remade it a bit taller, for a can that is 4.815in [122.3mm] tall. Then I added a bit of text, "engraved" into one side of the handle. I also felt that the original made the can a bit easy to tip over, so I added a cross-base that can be glued in, if you like, but works just fine laid in the groove, since the can holds it in place.
I've included the source, autocad, files I used to make them, as well as a Blank version, you could modify as you like. Each version has both a "parts only" and an "anchored" version. The anchors are very thin (1 layer ~.008 [.21] thick), but hold the corners down better to fight curling off the print surface, when you print. The anchors trim away easily. I also used 45 degree chamfered, rather than fillet, along the bottom edges, so there is no radical overhang on that second and third layer.
The models are in inches. Each source file has the two arcs necessary for the arced text you might want to add, like I did.
When I printed the one in the pic, I used PLA @ 210 degrees 1st layer, 175 after, cooling fan on after 2nd layer. Heated glass surface @ 50 degrees C, with a very thin layer of glue stick. Heat turned off after 3rd layer. A layer height of .21mm. It was printed on an extremely modified Botmill (Prusa original copy), with a .35 mm J-Head. The first layer was printed at a speed of ~30mm, the rest 30mm perimeters, 60mm infill. It was printed with 3 walls, 2 floors, 4 tops layers and 15% infill. One other thing, to make sure it fits the can you want, I added a thin slice from the center of the handle, called "Test Slice". Print it and see if it fits your can, before wasting a bunch of filament...

title: Rostock Max v2 Layer Fan Shroud 30mm

description.text:
I needed to get my layer fans working again after many modifications to my hotend mount.  I found that I had three 30mm box fans sitting around, but all the shroud designs I could find were either for 30mm squirrel-cage fans or 40mm box fans.  So I made this.
One nice thing:  I had been playing with some other ducts that had a slight interference with the axles on the effector plate.  There is very little room at the corners, actually.  The original shroud design that I borrowed/stole (see below) was narrower, though, and even with my modifications, it does not interfere with the arms or axles anywhere during movement.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: The end of this will be near your hotend, and the mounting screw holes take a bit of strain, so ABS is preferred. PLA will also work, it will just be more likely to break/melt, so you might have to replace it sooner.

I started with the layer fan shroud mentioned in the assembly guide: http://repables.com/r/212 Then I loaded that model up in OpenSCAD. I knocked off the side tabs (not sure why they're there anyway), added a block with fan passthrough and mounting holes, then added the ducting to convert between (difference of polyhedron()s, if you're at all curious). I also added a thin bar along the bottom to force the air closer to the hotend before it escapes, and added two blocks to tighten up the effector-plate mounting and hold the duct as high as possible.

comments.text: Thanks, I have been looking for that small blower everywhere, but it seems difficult to come by... With your design I can use a standard 30mm fan, those are cheap and for sale everywhere. So that's convenient!

description.text: Legs and a drain attachment for making an automated sprouter from any plastic container(s) as seen in my youtube video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OY2Ezu5GYMo The outer container is a store-bought item about 8" deep, 12" wide and 9" tall. These legs allow it to tilt toward one corner, where you install the drain piece. all parts go on the outside. It's snug enough to prevent leaks since this is a low-water-pressure application. The sprouter trays are containers from Ikea (three pack of food-grade containers with lids, about 5" wide, 7" long and 2" tall). These are best attached with stainless steel pan-head bolts, #4 x 1/4" (you need 6 bolts and 6 nuts). I used bolt depot product# 6902 and 4115 (as pictured). For complete parts and assembly, please check out the youtube video.

After a year with my printer, the standard threaded rods started to get annoying. I decided to upgrade my printer with proper lead screws.
I couldn't find a set that I was sure would fit my printer, so I made one myself. Now you don't have to. This set fits the standard Prusa i3 with 8mm straight rods, 8mm lead screws and Nema 17 motors. update #1 :
included .skp files for further customization update #2 :
modified the right X axis carriage to include a recess for the rim of the lead screw nut. update #3 :
fixed manifold problems with X carriage parts. More information and photos can be found here:
http://harariprojects.com/2015/11/18/3d-printer-lead-screw-upgrade/ For more of my projects:
http://HarariProjects.com/

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

40%

Notes: printed with pla.

comments.author: bronks

comments.text: PLA has its problems; with a humidity above 50% the pieces only last 3 years, because this material absorbs water, getting more and more fragile as time passes by. I recommend only ABS if you expect your printer to last more than 2 years (or be prepared to print the stressed pieces in less time).

comments.author: dtiger1138

comments.text: found the solution. just have to rotate the bearing so it will slide out. Needed to use a spare 8mm rod for leverage.
comments.author: dtiger1138

comments.text:
The solution was just a few scrolls down, but glad to hear you got it.
the knurl nuts I used are 5mm OD, M3 thread and 5mm height. I print the hole for them a bit smaller than the OD, ~4.5mm + print shrinkage.
The hole doesn't have a step or anything, it's just a hole all the way through. I make sure to insert the nuts on the opposite side of the print so it actually grabs as you tighten the screw and not just bottoms out.

title: E3D v5 or v6 X-Carriage mount for standard Prusa i3

description.text:
I'm uploading my files by request!
The Photo is OLD! My printer is working for like one month with this modification and I didn't had any issues with it! Great holder by Tech2C! If you don't want issues with collisions between the parts - read the bottom of this page (the PRO tips!!!).
It's for standard Prusa i3 X carriage - the "T"-shaped one. The holes are 23.5mm apart (I think my carriage is with 24mm spacing but they work on my printer) - measured with callipers. The sensor holder is for 12mm sensor! The screws are M3x16. The hotend is v6 or v5 (mine is v5).
The center of the nozzle is 31mm from the front face of the carriage (the original length is reduced to fit my Y axis movement - 200mm - the end-stop is triggered by the left LM8UU linear bearing).
My Marlin options for the sensor that are working just fine:
define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 34 //To the RIGHT of the nozzle - in the 3D model --> 33.15mm
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -7 //To the BACK of the nozzle - in the 3D model --> -14.125mm
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -1.65 //HERE PLEASE, START AT 0! The minus means that my nozzle goes DOWN after the autobed leveling procedure!!! For 18mm capacitive or inductive sensor of the original E3D holder made by Tech2C, please go here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1132723 -> An impressive work by mariors50!
My make is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:164687 Update #1: Added mirrored versions of the carriage and the sensor holder -> For the sensor on the LEFT side! Update #2: Added the 18mm sensor holder. It's universal and can be mounted on the right and on the left side of the carriage. The parameters (based on the 3D model): 39.5mm to the RIGHT of the hotend; 13.375mm to the BACK of the nozzle. Use these settings in Marlin! My 3D model was based on LJC18A3-B-Z/AY capacitive sensor - this is the one I have laying around (on my printer - I decided to upgrade to Aluminium heatbed so I have been using M12 Inductive sensor and I'm happy with the results). Be careful with the collisions between this sensor and the Right Z-axis motor coupler! I can't test this sensor! Try to play with the M3 screws that are holding the sensormount and try to rotate the sensor a little bit if you have big coupler on the Z-axis! Ultimate PRO tip #1: The hot end clamp is tightened with M4 screws. Tighten the RIGHT one a little bit more on the standard Prusa i3! This will left some room between the PC Fan and the left motor coupler! The PC fan holder is fragile! You don't want to break it! Ultimate PRO tip #2: As you can see, my holder has 2 mounting holes on top of the horizontal beam and 2 mounting holes on the bottom of it. If you need more space in the Z axis and fairly small couplers for the motors of it, you can mount the whole holder on the 2 bottom holes - this will rise the maximum Z axis travel with ~20mm.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Homemade Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50-70%

Notes: Print in ABS - this is crucial!!!

Also - I have E3D V5 (Chinese clone) and it's working great for almost a year now. Because I left the dimensions of the part that holds the hotend as in the Tech2C's thing, I assume that it's good for V6 as well, because his is hotend is V6. :)
Cheers!

author: Dominiscan

description.text: I found the other FIM models posted around here to be delicate, low-resolution, wasteful of support material, and/or somewhat prone to print fails. I made these to remedy the situation. Based off of KP-Shadowsquirrel's 3D models on deviantArt (http://kp-shadowsquirrel.deviantart.com/gallery/24487513)

The "Simple" models are printed standing, and thus require more support material and do a poor job of taking advantage of anisotropic strength properties in layered plastic. Some people like the look of them though. The "MinSupportMaterial" models are printed at angles which reduce support material use somewhat while layering plastic along the limbs instead of perpendicular to the limbs to improve the strength of the print. Also, these behave a little like rafted prints, and are insulated somewhat from warp. The "Split" models are split down the middle, allowing for the layers to be parallel to most of the limbs, further improving the strength of the print, and allowing for even less support material use. Also seems to give a very nice surface finish. The downside to this method is that you must then glue the two halves together, and you may get a seam if the print isn't perfect.  
These files work well with Slic3r. I have not tested them with other G-code Generators. Most of these can be printed on a typical Prusa at 1000% scale. at 1000% The split Celestia model might be a bit large for a typical print bed though.

I wanted to print 4 crackers on a plate at 70%, but they did not scale well... the inner tube was too thick (and I also thought didn't need a lot of the material).
Additionally the "roof" of the inner tube would print badly without supports. So this version trims the inner tube and makes it a little thinner fixing most of those issues, It can now be layed flat without a roof. I have also printed at 50% for an electronics setup which worked a treat. Beware yee who scale smaller than 50%, It be untested waters :D

title: Yet Another Yoda - Keychain/Charm for Casting

description.text:
This is a remix of a remix of a remix, but I don't think we can ever get enough Yoda.  
I added a keychain/charm loop and scaled him down quite a bit.  The purpose was for an experiment in investment casting.  At this scale, with a FDM process, there is a thin spot in the ears that just ends up being empty space.  We repaired that with a little wax.  
All parts were printed in ABS (rather than PLA which is more commonly used for investment casting).  Some were vapor polished, and some were left as-printed.  A handful were then investment cast in silicon bronze.  
More information and a video of the process is up on our blog at printedsolid.com

description.text: Ever wanted to see Viewmaster reels but didn't have a Viewmaster viewer? Fret no more! Just swap the usual post card mount with this reel mount. The lens focal length for optimally viewing the Viewmaster reels in this contraption should be about 45mm (about the same as a Google Cardboard lens) This accessory complements this stereoscope: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1108267 Prints easily without support. Enjoy!

This is a knob designed to encase a 1/4" hex nut to create a threaded knob for use on a threaded stud. It can be used in a wide range of application where you need a hand securable knob on a carriage bolt or threaded rod.
The nut is inserted into the knob during the print run. It takes a little calculating and watching, but you can watch and pause the print when it has printed the last of the layers that make up the hex recess. If you are printing with 0.4mm layers, it will be after approximately the 25th layer.
It is designed for a 1/4-20 nut but could also be used with a 6M nut if printed at approximately 95%. Untested, but it should work with a range of nut diameters by changing the print size.

• Start printing the knob.
  • At the correct time pause the print.
  • Insert the hex nut into the recess.
  • Resume the printing. The plastic may not stick to the nut as printing is resumed but it will normally correct itself after a few layers.
  • You may need to ream the plastic of the hole some with a 1/4" drill to clean out any threads that have not stuck to the nut.

title: TDCS Electrode casing for OpenBCI
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
We are a team of engineers, neurobiologist’s and psychologists working on a new user-friendly, plug 'n’ play tDCS device. Until now, we have been testing different electrode-placements and types, using the awesome OpenBCI (http://openbci.com/) ULTRACORTEX frame.
We love OpenBCI and the opensource-strategy so we put our tDCS electrode casing up here. It is an humble contribution, that allows hackers to get started with the tDCS right away using the ULTRACORTEX, but we hope to share much more the coming weeks. We are crossing our fingers that OpenBCI reach their stretch goal with their KickStarter campaign and get to develop the tDCS shield. For those who can't wait: here you go! TDCS electrode-casing: 16cm^2 OpenBCI ultracortex frame https://github.com/OpenBCI/Ultracortex/tree/master/Mark_3/STLs). The casing fits snugly into the octabolts (see picture for assembly-instructions) and can rotate freely in order to adapt to different head-shapes and sizes. <3
Mindsettr.com ----------------UPDATE---------------- -Added electrode-casing with extended arm. In tests this was used on people with flatter back-heads and while testing Pz -Added holes for sewing the sponge to the casing

title: Sturdy Leg With Adjustable Foot For Kossel

description.text:
i created a nice looking adjustable leg for my 2020 printer. Someone asked for the same leg to fit their Kossel. Well, here it is.
The foot uses an M6 x 20-30mm hex bolt and the leg has space for an M6 hex nut. You may need to use a soldering iron or a little glue to keep the nut and bolt from falling out.
It uses M3 screws and t-nuts to attach to the 1515 rail. There is also a hole to screw into the end of the 1515 vertical upright.
There is also a version for the 2020 kossel. It uses the same foot and M4 hardware.
You can add a non-skid pad to the bottom of the foot to keep your printer from sliding around. 
Since I don't have a Kossel yet, let me know if there are any adjustments I need to make.

title: Auto Marble Machine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Remake of the 3D Printed Marble Machine #2 - Designed by Tulio Laanen (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:795952) including a small stepper motor for continuous operation. https://youtu.be/pe5QDOH1b50 A new base was added to house the motor, lights and electronics. I also add a small drawer to store the metal balls when not in use and a new cap instead of the turning blade. The lift was also modified to fit the motor and the cap. I didn't modify the track of the original design but then it has to be manually modified to fit the motor and lights. The modification consists in drilling a 9.5 mm hole through the base in the center of the lift housing to fit the motor, and drilling several 5 mm holes to fit the LED's. I used a small and inexpensive step motor 28BYJ-48 fixed with super-glue to the track base. The electronics are very simple: A PIC 16F628A programmed to generate 4 channels of sequenced pulses to the motor's driver ULN2003 and a 7.5 V 300 mA to power separatly the PIC, the motor driver and the LED's.

description.text:
See the robot in action
http://vimeo.com/67641975 The Ulti-BotBot is a submission by XYZ Workshop that won 6th place in a 3D Toy Design Competition organised by GrabCAD and Ultimaker. See results of the competition at http://grabcad.com/challenges/ultimaker-3d-printer-toy-design-challenge/results We wanted to push what we could do with the Ultimaker 3D printer, and we wanted to design something that was heavily articulated and not merely a static toy. Inspired while watching the Octonauts cartoon with our son, our early sketches for a toy came about as a robot tank, with articulated arms that would pick up objects and collect them on its back. It would then poopÃÂ the objects out through a rear hatch. The initial concept of the robot, was to pick up purposefully designed 3D printed objects. However, it then struck us that it would be cool and less of a choking hazard if the robot picked up chocolate snacks instead. Maltesers first came to mind as the perfect object to be used, as they resembled mini cannon balls Alas, upon testing, they were of the wrong scale and proportion to our design. This realization was followed by a series of rigorous testing and experimentation of different chocolate confectioneries. Our extensive research lead us to conclude that using something smaller, namely M&Ms, Skittles or Smarties would be more appropriate. The best thing was that nobody went hungry during those late night experimentations. As the design developed, the thought came to us, what if it could shoot out chocolate confectionery from its very own cannon? We then designed a working chocolate cannon, utilising the spring from an ordinary pen. Forget all those negative press about people building their own 3d printed guns. Why not build your own 3d printed chocolate cannon! This is chocolate warfare about to be taken to the next level! If you like our designs please follow us at http://www.facebook.com/xyzworkshop

The Ulti-BoBot is approximately 126mm wide,104mm deep and 155mm in height (excluding the cannon and arms).It is made up of a total of 37 assembled parts. (Not including the Ultimaker figure and spring). It was printed using a combination of flexible black Ultimaker PLA, silver and yellow Ultimaker PLA.  
Most of the parts are designed to snap together. The articulated arm's ball and socket joints were printed at 150 micron on a raft. We had to slow the print down to 15mm/s as the head kept knocking the delicate socket legs off.  
The main body, claws and control cockpit were printed with supports turned on. This ensures the moving joints would be printed properly. Extra care is required when trying to loosen the pin joint of the main body's rear hatch.  
The tank tracks were printed using Ultimaker's flexible PLA. This was printed at 200 microns and reduced to 15mm/s speed.  
The spring used for the cannon is from a uniball jetstream click pen. It's external diameter measures 4.5mm and 28mm long.

comments.text: I'm having a lot of trouble printing the tank tread in TPU. As the edges of the tread are tapered, during my print I have one (or both) of a) coming off the print bed during printing, and b) the first few layers not bonding very well as the taper is unsupported. Next time I'm going to try adding supports in key areas of the first few layers (it seems to be primarily the curved areas where they start to get unstuck) and seeing if that helps.

title: CobbleBot Horizontal X Axis Mod V3

description.text:
This is version 3 of my CobbleBot X Axis mod. Don't bother looking for verison 2, I did not post it. This has completely removed the issue of X backlash for me and I can now properly print with my printer. This mod basically attaches a drive shaft to the X stepper motor that then drives two belt pulleys. One at the top of the X plane and one at the bottom. This keeps each end of the Y axis moving as one. The stepper is mounted outside the frame of the gantry and the drive shaft runs just underneath the gantry. The coupler for the drive shaft is inside the stepper mount. There is a slot in the stepper mount for turning the set screws on the coupler. In addition to the printed parts you are going to need four 625 radial bearings, two idler pulleys, a 5mm drive shaft, two 5mm pulleys, and a 5mm to 5mm coupler. Here are the ones I used: Bearing - http://openbuildspartstore.com/ball-bearing-625-2rs-5x16x5/
Idler - http://openbuildspartstore.com/smooth-idler-pulley-wheel-kit/
Pulley - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00THZJNTI?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00
Coupler - http://www.amazon.com/EnPoint-Flexible-Aluminum-Coupling-Backlash/dp/B016F2E92G/ref=sr_1_7?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1447884138&sr=1-7&keywords=enpoint+5mm+coupler The drive shaft is a 5mm drill rod that I got from McMaster Carr, but their website doesnt allow me to directly link to it. It is literally 5mm which the hole in the bearings are actually a little smaller than 5mm. To compensate for this I had to put the drill rod into a drill and use sand paper to take off a few thousandths to get the bearings over the drive shaft. You will also need screws and t nuts to mount everything to the vslot rails. As always I have included the google sketchup files so people can easily make changes. EDIT: Added some additional pictures of the motor mount. You can see the slot on the top for accessing the set screws for the coupler. Update 2016-01-18:
  • Modified the X-Axis-Idler-Mount so it can get closer to the rails
  • Modified the X-Axis-Drive-Shaft-Mount so it can get closer to the rails.
  • Modified the X-Axis-Drive-Shaft-Mount to strengthen the area around the bearings.
    • Update: 2016-02-04:
  • Created a new X-Axis-Drive-Shaft-Mount that is very different than my other design. This design can be printed without supports and with the bearing holder laying flat. The print quality is much better with it. You should print four of this one, two of which you should invert so the bearing mount is on the other side. This allows you to spread the bearings out evenly along the drive shaft rather than just at the ends.
    • Update: 2016-04-08:
  • Change the X-Axis-Idler-Mount so that the tension is adjustable and prints without supports. Requires 2 35mm M3 bolts and 2 M3 nuts to hold the two halves together. For the Idler adjustments you need 2 15mm M5 bolts and 2 M5 nuts plus a 30mm length of 5mm diameter rod.
    • Update: 2017-09-20:
  • Redesigned the X-Axis-Drive-Shaft-Mount mount yet again. This time in Fusion360. The part is stronger and has two attachment points instead of one. It can still be printed without supports. I recommend at least 50% infill for strength. You will need 2x M4 nuts and appropriate t-slot bolts for mounting. I added a chamfer to make pressing the bearing in easier. I recommend a C clamp for that.

comments.text: Hello, thanks for sharing your design. I am also planning to apply it to my Cobblebot Basic. I have printed the stepper mount and will continue with the rest tonight. I am new to 3D printing; just wanted to clarify the use of the 30 mm length 5 mm diameter rod ('For the Idler adjustments you need 2 15mm M5 bolts and 2 M5 nuts plus a 30mm length of 5mm diameter rod.')
comments.author: jonmohajer1

comments.text: Sorry for the delayed response. The part you are quoting is for the idlers not the drive pulleys. The 5mm drive shaft I got was 500mm and I cut it to size once installed on the printer. I ordered it from McMaster Carr. If you can find stainless steel in 5mm diameter I recommend it. Mine is drill rod and it gets a small layer of rust on it that I have to clean off every so often. I would think 400mm should be enough though.
comments.author: jonmohajer1

comments.text: I'm ordering parts to try your mod. Which length m5 bolts will I need for your drive shaft/idler mounts? Also curious why you went with a 16 tooth pulley instead of 20. Thanks for the design!

author: lImbus

description.text: This is a variation on a previously posted base mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:999592 and/or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:999609 from FTC team(s) 4224 & 6780. Due to the problems surrounding the USB cable issue(s), and a few comments for a EKOCYCLE friendly model, this new version will hopefully be an improvement. Since several FTC teams are using the EKOCYCLE, it's been shaved down to fit the 6"x6" print bed. Also, to help with the loose cable problem, the micro-USB opening has been narrowed for a tighter fit. A support pad, and two zip-tie retainer holes, were also added and can be used if you feel necessary. This mounting base is designed to be compatible with the same cover as previous versions, and can be found here; http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:999616. Mounting holes are sized to self-tap using 6-32 / T-32 SHCS, 5/16 long. Edit: The model orientation shown in Thingiview isn't correct. I've adjusted the drawing planes, re-uploaded, and the problem remains. Model should lay on it's back for best printing results. If someone has a suggestion on how to fix that please comment!

This is a traffic cone, printed on a Makerbot rep2.
The color percentages are put like we call it "from the eye", and I am quite amazed that it turned out this good. It can have a use as a ring holder.
P.S. the base is not hollow so you cannot stack them on each other. For those that want to print this, and have the time and energy to change filaments 6 times.... the printing sequence works like this. Start with red and continue up until 35%.
Put white and continue up until 47%.
Put red and continue up until 60%
White until 70%
Red until 80%
White until 90%
Red until 100. Like always, this is inspired by search engine page 1.
If you want to help a brother out check http://facebook.com/free3dcph
Enjoy ! UPDATE!
I have added a file traffic_cone_hollow_base for those that want to stack the cones. Idea by mb20music.

description.text: Inspired by "[another] M.C.Escher fish" and based on http://www.mcescher.com/gallery/symmetry/no-20-fish/, here's a 3D-printable model. This is quite challenging to print accurately enough to tessellate multiple objects... many of mine needed some sanding or carving to make them fit. The bottom surface is chamfered so that any excess on the first layer won't interfere with the outline. I've shrunk the outline by 0.25mm to make it easier to fit together. Anyone wanting to adapt this (reduce the tolerance from 0.25mm?) or see how it's done can get the model from OnShape.com -- search Public documents for "Escher Fish".

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Doesn't Matter

10% is fine

author: kapitimartin

description.text:
This thing is a very simple replacement part for a Syma X5SC quadcopter's foot. This design prints much faster (takes just a few minutes to print) and is lighter than my previous one (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1141251). It's also lighter than an original Syma foot. You will need two pieces of 3mm diameter filament (about 6-7cm long) that will take place in the 3mm diameter holes at the base (going thru it about 7mm - see photo) and the two other 3mm diameter holes at the tip. If you're using ABS, they can be glued in place with the use of acetone.
I printed the parts with ABS but used HDPE for the filament parts (unglued).
I think HDPE filament does a better job because it's softer and bends easily without breaking which is a good point here.
Just mount it like the original foot and fix it with the help of the original small screw. This foot design is
  • easy and fast to print
  • light
  • strong
  • nearly unbreakable
  • modular (length)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm layer thickness

Infill:

25%

My latest interactive puzzle poster design is another challenging 3D printing project but with the added bonus of being connected to a very worthwhile charitable cause! http://nifty50.sociodesign.co.uk It would make a great hanging artwork or even a puzzle with a contemporary theme for bigger kids! A collaboration with a designer friend of mine.
50 Designers x50 Posters. A poster project that challenges participants to creatively interpret the word 'Money' in aid of @CMHCharity organised by @SocioDesign
http://nifty50.sociodesign.co.uk/bidding/57/wolff-olins/the-goods-life I'm hoping it'll attract lots of interest and help raise loads of money for the receiving charity
http://cmhcharity.org.uk The auction has only a few days left, so if you would like to bid for this or any of the great designs, then please go ahead and support a great cause! However, if you fancy a 3D printing challenge, then here it is for free - i'm sure someone will buy the original! Enjoy! UPDATE: 090916
Amended a small issue with the 'Heel' part.
V2 versions:
The_Goods_Life_Heels_1_v2.stl
The_Goods_Life_Heels_3_v2.stl

MakerBot

No

Notes: Printed with Faberdashery PLA http://www.faberdashery.co.uk
48 pieces of the poster jigsaw to print. No support or raft needed.
Print at a high res to retain detail. The full poster size is A2 (420x594mm)
But it should be okay to scale 50% and the pieces should fit together - if you're over extruding, you may have fit issues at smaller sizes.

All my own creations, except the Lamborghini and heels, adapted 3d models from these great sites: http://www.dmi-3d.net/modelscar9.html and http://archive3d.net/?tag=high%20heels

description.text:
I modeled this after my Bach 7C Euphonium (Though I think its really for trombone) mouthpiece. Its the schools, so Im assuming its a pretty common/beginner size. The model isnt perfect, but I got it pretty accutate. These things are very counter-intuitive in design, but the model works great inside and out. I cant wait till I get my vapor bath stuff, then it will really feel nice.   
Also, being in my school marching band, it will be great for the winter as it wont actually get so cold! :D  
The rim is flat in the model, unlike the real thing for ease of printing. Nothing some sanding cant fix.  
I may upload a comparison to the origional to youtube soon. If I do Ill post it.
